headline: Laura Coates Live
subHeadline: Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson Won't Endorse Biden After Backing Him In 2020; RFK Jr. Downplays January 6 Attack; CNN Presents "Who's Talking To Chris Wallace." Aired 11p-12a ET

utterances.speaker: JIM SCIUTTO, CNN CHIEF NATIONAL SECURITY ANALYST
utterances.sentences: And to the memory of all those crew members. Thank you, Kaycee Anderson for joining us and sharing --KAYCEE ANDERSON, DAUGHTER OF ASTRONAUT MICHAEL P. ANDERSON:  Thank you.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: -- your thoughts on this. Well, please don't forget this Sunday, the brand-new CNN Original Series, "Space Shuttle ColumbiaAnd thanks so much to all of you for watching "NEWSNIGHT." I'm Jim Sciutto in Washington, and LAURA COATES LIVE starts right now. Hi, Laura.

utterances.speaker: LAURA COATES, CNN HOST AND SENIOR LEGAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: Tonight on LAURA COATES LIVE, time to get up enthusiastic. The big interview with Curb Your Enthusiasm's Larry David. Wait until you hear what happens when Chris Wallace asks Larry the question he doesn't want to answer.So, all you Curb fans can probably guess what will happen next. And Larry David, he definitely does not shy away from politics at all, and you'll want to hear what he really thinks of Donald Trump. And if you suddenly hear babies crying, don't blame me. That and much more in their full interview just a few moments away. But first, look, not everyone in Hollywood wants to talk about politics. "The Rock," AKA Dwayne Johnson, says he will not endorse Joe Biden or anybody this time around. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DWAYNE JOHNSON, ACTOR
utterances.sentences: The endorsement that I made years ago with Biden was one I thought was the best decision for me at that time. Am I going to do that again this year? That answer is no. I'm not going to do that because what I realized, what that caused back then was something that tears me up in my guts back then and now, which is division, and that got me.(END VIDEO CLIP) COATES:  You know what else is raising some eyebrows or maybe just the one eyebrow from "The Rock?" Anyway, he goes on to say he'll keep his politics to himself. So, here's the thing. That's very different than what he chose to do in 2020. If you look back, here's how he endorsed the Biden-Harris ticket back then. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: So, I figured let's kick this conversation off this way by me officially publicly endorsing you both to become president and vice president of our great country.

utterances.speaker: KAMALA HARRIS, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: Oh, that's fantastic.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.sentences: Thank you, thank you, thank you

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: -- for real. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Really, thank you.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: You guys are both obviously experienced to lead. You've done great things. Joe, you've had such an incredible career. You've led, in my opinion, with great compassion and heart and drive, but also soul.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Now, remember, "The Rock" is not your average celebrity endorser, by the way. He says that he was approached, recall, by unnamed parties in 2022, asking if he would run for president himself. He has even cited hypothetical polls that show him getting support in the 40s. And while he ruled out a run this year, I didn't hear him ruling out a run in the future. I wonder how all of these fits into perhaps a master plan.Now I want to bring in Shermichael Singleton, a CNN political commentator and former deputy chief of staff of Housing and Urban Development under Donald Trump, and Kate Bedingfield, a CNN political commentator and former Biden White House communications director. I'm so glad that you're both here. I'm going to try not to show my WrestleMania past -- (LAUGHTER) -- but it's there. (LAUGHTER) Kate, let me begin with you here because, first of all, the idea of the endorsement or not endorsing, it's quite a thing. Did anyone ask him, per se, to describe it in this way? He seemed like he really wanted this to be known. Why do you think that is the case?

utterances.speaker: KATE BEDINGFIELD, CNN POLITICAL COMMENTATOR
utterances.sentences: Well, it seems to me pretty clear this is a celebrity protecting his own personal brand. I mean, he made the decision to go on Fox. If you listen to the rest of the interview, he talks about his concern about woke culture in the United States. He's clearly thinking about his own brand. He's clearly sorts of trying to, you know, correct -- course correct for his own personal -- his own personal reasons.Um, so, you know, I don't know that this is so much a reflection on Biden as it is an effort by a celebrity to sort of say, you know, I stuck my toe in the pool of politics, I didn't love it, and now I'm trying to adjust and pull back. I think it's a little ironic to go on Fox News and talk about how you reject division and hate the division that you see in the country given what Fox News does, but -- but I think that it's very clear. I think, you know, he and his PR team sat down and were trying to figure out how they could pull him out of politics for his own personal brand.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: You know, of course -- I mean, I'm equally curious about how people think and how they vote, as we all are in many ways, but it's the way that, as Kate is talking about, that he wanted to make sure it was known that he wasn't going to do anything this time around, and there are many celebrities who love being very much a part of it.

utterances.speaker: SHERMICHAEL SINGLETON, CNN POLITICAL COMMENTATOR, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: I mean, not only did he say he was out, he was asked, did he think President Biden is doing a good job? He pretty much said no. He was asked if he thinks the country is headed in the right direction, he pretty much said no. I think this is a consistent and a persistent pattern that you see with Americans, including some Democrats, in terms of how they feel about President Biden and the direction of the country overall.You just happen to have "The Rock," who's one of the biggest celebrities in the world, sort of mimicking, if you will, what many other people are saying on the streets in their everyday lives which is, we don't believe the country is better under the Biden administration, and we want somebody else. Unfortunately, we have two people that nobody wants with Biden and former President Trump.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: You know, interestingly, from "The Rock" to maybe the sinking poll numbers for Biden in many respects, he certainly wants it to be much higher, Kate. He wants people to associate his administration with success and good feeling. Now, he can tout a lot of things, but there is a disconnect between people, say, they are feeling in polls. How do you get around that? I mean, he has had these many accomplishments.

utterances.speaker: BEDINGFIELD
utterances.sentences: Uh-hmm.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: But when you look at how voters think the issues can be handled best, I mean, Trump leads in the economy, immigration, mental and physical fitness. Of course, abortion and democracy, Biden is there as well. What does that suggest to you?

utterances.speaker: BEDINGFIELD
utterances.sentences: Well, I think, first of all, I would say we have seen over the last month, really since the State of the Union, so more than a month, six weeks, we have seen polls slowly start to tick up in Joe Biden's favor. We've seen that in the battleground states. Obviously, not where he wants to be yet, but moving in the right direction.You know, I think there's also -- we've also seen good economic news. We saw a gangbuster jobs report just yesterday or this morning even. What is time anymore? I don't know. But -- (LAUGHTER) -- you know, that was better than people anticipated. So, you know, there continue to be economic indicators that are strong. Now, yes, is there a disconnect between how people are feeling, the sense of unease that people have, and substantively where the economy is? Yes. And so, it is on President Biden and the Biden campaign to spend the next seven months talking about not just what they've done, not just what they've passed, not just the bills, but really how they have made a difference in people's lives. And I think they have a very good story to tell about his focus on kitchen table issues and on what matters to middle class families. And don't forget, he's running against Donald Trump, whose entire message is about Donald Trump and about himself, and is not in any way about how he's going to -- how his second term is going to make life better for working people. So, the Biden campaign also has to drive that contrast for the next seven months.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Well, here's a contrast for both of you. What RFK Jr. thinks happened on January 6th in terms of weapons or people approaching, I'm using the term loosely here, approaching the Capitol, and what he's now saying. I want to play for a little bit here because earlier, he said today that January 6th might not have been a real insurrection, that protesters carried no weapons, and then a few hours later, he retracted that, saying that he was wrong.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) Now, of course, these were all knowable facts. I'm not sure how one misconstrues or misunderstands given, of course, we've heard many a moment talking about the bear spray, the mace. (END VIDEO CLIP) There is the idea of the knives. You've got the comments from the January 6th committee talking about Trump through Cassidy Hutchinson's testimony, saying that they're not here for me, don't have them use the magnetometers or whatever it would be. How did he get this so wrong?

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: I mean, this is like the oddity with Robert F. Kennedy. I mean, in one vein, he appears to want to be an uber left liberal, and the other vein, he clearly wants to be somewhat like Trump, appealing to some of those Republican voters who may think there is a better alternative. It's just odd. It's just weird.I mean, I think the evidence on this is pretty straight clear. We've had a year and a half worth of individuals coming out, testifying publicly about it. I think it was a catastrophic mistake. I'm not exactly sure what RFK Jr. was thinking here. I think he needs to probably focus on what is his path when there really isn't one to try to continue forward over the next couple of months. He selected a running mate that no one knows anything about. And when you really look at some of his policy positions, they really are sort of indistinguishable in terms of how they actually are going to address many of the issues that people are actually facing. So, this is a blunder, a terrible mistake. His folks need to figure out what his message is going to be moving forward. This shouldn't be it.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: A blunder or an attempt to envelop independents or Trump voters?

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: So, when you hear that, is that -- does that explain in some way to you why, and I'm not justifying it, but does that explain or give some insight as to why he's trying to bridge these gaps?

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: I mean, maybe because, again, to Kate's point, maybe he's trying to appeal to some of those voters. But, look, there are a lot of people who believe the election was stolen regardless of what we may think. Those folks are out there. It is a sizable percent of Donald Trump's base.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: But is it enough to convert a voter for Trump?

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: No, absolutely not. I mean, the folks who supported Trump are impeccably loyal. I mean, those. I mean, those folks would literally walk off a bridge for Donald Trump if it meant helping him get back into the White House. Whatever Robert F. Kennedy says, whatever position, policy position he tries to adopt, is not going to persuade any of those people.Now, if there is a more nationalized conversation about what do we do after the election, let's say Trump doesn't win in terms of reaching out to those people, then I think we're all a part of wanting to have that dialogue, but this isn't it.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Real quick, Kate, final word.

utterances.speaker: BEDINGFIELD
utterances.sentences: I agree. I agree with that. I mean, I don't know who he thinks his audience is for this. This is not going to be an argument that's going to peel away a Donald Trump voter, and it is certainly not going to appeal to a Biden voter or even somebody there in the middle.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Hmm, I wonder what it's going to do. Shermichael, Kate, thank you both so much.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Laura.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Now, let's turn over to our friends at Max with "Curb Your Enthusiasm" 12-season run coming to close this Sunday. Chris Wallace talks to the show's star and creator, Larry David, about T.V., politics, and life itself. Here is "Who's Talking to Chris Wallace."(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: CHRIS WALLACE, BROADCAST JOURNALIST
utterances.sentences: Larry David, welcome. It's so good to be with you again.LARRY DAVID, COMEDIAN AND WRITER, STAR AND CREATOR OF "CURB YOUR ENTHUSIASM":  Thank you so much, Chris. Um, this isn't going to take very long, right? What are we, like, a couple of minutes, five minutes? Because, you know, I don't really sit with people as a rule for a long time, even dinners.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You and I have had dinner, and we sat there for an hour.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Was it an hour?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yeah. Did it feel longer?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Felt like three, yeah.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, this will --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: This will be shorter than dinner.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: All right, good.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: We're coming to the end of season 12 of "Curb Your Enthusiasm," and I got to say, you are on fire. In one episode, you get in a fight with a hotel maid, a waiter who has lost his mother, and even with the Siri device in your car. Here's that one.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Siri, directions to Wolfsglen.UNKNOWN (voice-over):  Directions to Great Wolf Lodge.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: No, Siri, Wolfsglen Restaurant.UNKNOWN (voice-over):  One option I see, Wood's Garden Supply on Benedict Canyon.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Siri, Wolfsglen Restaurant in Westwood. UNKNOWN (voice-over)

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: No, no, no, you're not listening!(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It -- it gets a lot worse than that.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But in any case, I was going to use --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: By the way, that scene, the night -- the night that happened, when I was going someplace, that's actually how I reacted.(LAUGHTER) Just everything you see in that scene is what I did. And I came in the next day. I said, listen, we've got to shoot this. This is really funny. And so, we did, and we put it in the first show.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Why is it that so many things in life, like Siri, trigger you?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I --(LAUGHTER) -- I have a very low tolerance for stupidity in myself and in others. And so -- I don't know. I just notice things that maybe -- I don't know. Maybe other people don't or -- or I think I just-- things impact me more. And I have an outlet to do it. I'm sure people have had a situation like that in their car, but what can they do with it? Just tell their friend, hey, has this happened to you or isn't this awful or whatever? But I'm lucky enough that, well, I had a show that I could put it on.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It stood on for a little bit longer.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God. Oh, my God. What's going on here? What the fuck is this

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: And I --

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: All right, you two, you have really gone too far this time. Go out and get me a black jockey right now! You better fucking find one! And I want that purse back, too!

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: It's Giuliani! No wonder I thought he looked like an asshole!(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And I'm not even going to get into how we ended up with a black lawn jockey there. So, how much has the whole 2020 election and everything that has flowed from it pissed you off?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I mean, you can't go a day without thinking about what he has done to this country because he's such a little baby that he has thrown 250 years of democracy out the window by not accepting the results of it.I mean, it's so crazy. He's such a sociopath. He's so insane. He just couldn't admit to losing. And we know he lost. He knows he lost. And look how he has fooled everybody. He has convinced all these people that he didn't lose. He's such a sick man. He's so sick. Anyway, no, it hasn't impacted me at all. (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But, I mean, when you think about it, the, you know, the changing of the rules, the fact that you're not allowed to bring a bottle of water to somebody waiting on line in the heat.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: When I heard about that -- that law in Georgia, it was mind- blowing. What? You can't give a person a bottle of water or food if they're waiting on line to vote? It was the most preposterous thing I ever heard. It sounded like a sketch. And so, it became one, yeah.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It's all fodder for grist for the mill.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You announced in December that this is not the season finale but a series finale. This is the end of "Curb." How come?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: That's it? That's the answer?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I don't know. It was -- it was -- it was time. Twelve seasons. We've been doing it for 24 years. I mean, it's a long time. And -- I don't know. We really want to see an old guy on television just until he's in the 80s. I mean, how long can you watch?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It's too late. I already have him saying an old guy on television.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah. How long can you watch it? Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: What are you going to do with yourself?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I'll find some stuff, yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: In entertainment? Are you going to just play golf?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Oh, no, no, no. I'll do something, yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But "Curb," and this is final. This is --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: This is it, Chris. This is it.(LAUGHTER) I'm making a Sherman-esque statement. (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: If nominated, you will not --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: If nominated, I will not run. If elected, I will not serve.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: One thing that people have loved about "Curb" is the way that you find the absurdity in everyday life. And here's case in point, you driving to go see a Los Angeles Dodgers baseball game.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Oh, you should see the traffic. The only thing moving is the carpool lane. I'll never make it. I'm just going to go home. I'm not going to use the carpool lane by myself because I don't want to. Well, that's the difference between you and me. All right, goodbye.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Hey, Daddy, you want to date with Mama?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Get in the car.(END VIDEO CLIP) (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: The kicker here is that your crew goes to the game, shoots some footage of the game, and you ended up being the excuse, having evidence that showed that a guy didn't commit a crime and, therefore, didn't have to go to prison?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I know, you are kind of a hero.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah, I saved someone's life inadvertently.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: The only way you'd ever do it.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: The only way I could ever do it, yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: In 2020, in "Curb," you discovered the advantages to wearing a MAGA hat.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: All right, two seats at the sushi bar. You know what? Actually, I think we'd prefer to sit at a table, please. Huh.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Sad. Very sad.(END VIDEO CLIP) (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: In your world here, because, you know, you live in Beverly Hills or Santa Monica or something like that, what would wearing a MAGA hat do?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I'm sure you'd get some very odd looks in Los Angeles if you were walking around with that hat. But, yeah, I used it on a show. Got me out of a couple of things. I was going to get beat up by --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: A biker.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: A biker, yeah. Then I put the hat on.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: How do you wrap your head around the fact that he could very well be a reelected president? I mean, right now, I'd say he's the favorite.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: He's just such an amazing conman. He has such a gift for lying and fooling people and convincing people of something that's a complete lie.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But the fact -- but the point is, millions and millions and millions of Americans, more so than three years ago, they buy it.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: They buy it. It's a testament to his conning abilities. He's the greatest conman we've ever produced, yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, that's something.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: We're back with more "Who's talking to Chris Wallace?" Well, he's talking to Larry David. Here it is.(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You started "Seinfeld" in 1989. And I want to play a clip from perhaps the most famous episode, the contest that won you an Emmy and TV Guide, that great authority, said was the greatest episode of T.V. ever.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Is that right?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yeah.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: I want to be in on this, too.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Oh, no, no, no.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Why? What? Why? Why?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Because you're a woman.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: So, what?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: It's easier for a woman not to do it than a man. We have to do it. It's part of our lifestyle.(LAUGHTER) It's like shaving.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Oh, that is such a baloney. I shave my legs.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Not every day.(LAUGHTER) (END VIDEO CLIP) (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So, first of all, how'd you come up with that idea? DAVID

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Literally?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Literally.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: That -- that contest?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: That contest.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Who -- who -- who could put it off longer?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes. Had a contest.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And then what were the results of said contest?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I was clearly the winner. Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: What'd you go, two days?(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Anyway, that's where that came from.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And how much trouble did you have getting it past the NBC censors?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Um, usually, the network would -- they would -- when they would come into the room after a show or after a run-through, they would look at our board and see upcoming shows. And they'd say, what's that one about? What's that one about?And for the contest, I didn't put it up on the board because I didn't want them asking what it was about because I knew they wouldn't do it. They came to a read-through. They heard the show.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: And in my head, I'm going, well, if they don't let -- if they don't let us do this, I'm done, I'm quitting. As soon as they say no, we're not doing it. And I've got the whole speech in my head.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Sorry, good luck, I'm done. You know, that's what I was going to do. I was going to quit. But then we had the read-through.  It got great laughs. They came back to our office, and they didn't say a word. I was stunned.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Maybe a little disappointed, too.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah, it would have been a good scene. (LAUGHTER)I missed that on a big dramatic moment.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So why do you think they'd let it go?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I don't know. I guess because they heard laughs. And when they hear laughs, it kind of changes their thinking about something.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: There's another episode I love in which George is trying to impress a girlfriend at a kid's birthday party.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Smoke? Everybody? I think I smell some smoke back here.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Fire!(SCREAMS)

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: It was an inferno in there! An inferno!

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: There he is! That's him!(END VIDEO CLIP) (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So -- and George, it's supposedly based on you, so same question. How do you live with yourself?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: How do I live with myself? It's -- again, it's not easy. Yeah, it is not easy. I don't know. I just try and get into a routine. And so, if I do the same thing tomorrow that I'm doing today without, of course, seeing you, I've got through it. And okay, do the same thing, you'll get through that one, too. So, I have to have -- I have to have a very regimented life. I don't like traveling. I don't like going anywhere. I like -- I like going to the office.(LAUGHTER) I like going to the office. I like playing golf. I like being in my house. (LAUGHTER) I'm so dull and uninteresting. I really don't enjoy being out and socializing and making small talk. I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Is this a bit that you're doing for me?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: No, it's not a bit. It's not a bit. It's not a bit. Ask anybody who knows me.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So why are you laughing?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: You know what? I wish it was a bit. I wish it was. I long to be somebody else. I wish I could enjoy things that most people enjoy. But I can't. Yeah. I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I mean --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Something -- something went off somewhere.(LAUGHTER) Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Something went terribly wrong?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Something went wrong, Chris.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Speaking of things going wrong, you wrote for "Saturday Night Live" --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: -- for one season.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Well, you've really done some -- some background stuff.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yeah. And the story I heard is you're -- you're writing for "Saturday Night Live," an entire season.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You get one sketch on the air.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And you get so fed up that at one point, one night, you go to the executive producer and you say to him, I quit.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And you realized overnight.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: It was laced with profanity, by the way. The I quit speech.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yeah, right.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: It was the one that I was going to deliver to the "Seinfeld."

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: About the contest.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah, about the contest.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But this time --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: This time I actually did it, yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Okay. And that overnight, you realize this is a big mistake and that you show up for work on Monday pretending nothing ever happened.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Is that a true story?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah, 100%, yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And how did that go?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: It went well.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I mean, did nobody say, hey, what are you doing here?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: No, I got some odd looks from the writers, people who witnessed my meltdown. And the executive producer who was running it didn't see. He asked me what I was working on. And I told him, and then he moved on to the next person.I just sat there. He went down the line of the writers, asked them what they were working on, got to me, what are you working on? I told him, and then he went to the next one.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And you turned this into a storyline for George, who at one point --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: George, yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: -- quits --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: -- realizes it's a mistake, comes back to work --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah. Yeah, pretends it never happened.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I think you're not as maladjusted as you think you are. Although I do have a story to tell. You and I went to dinner with your lovely wife, Ashley -- DAVID

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: -- last fall. And you very nicely picked up the check. And the next day, I wrote you, I thought, a very gracious thank you note. And you then responded. And I have saved this. I literally quoted this. You wrote back to me and you said, keep in mind, next time when you pick up the check, you will not be getting a next day thanks.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: What's so objectionable about it?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: How many thank you do we have to give out?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I gave one.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: No, I understand. But if you take me out to dinner and I say, hey, Chris, thank you so much, why do I have to do? Where does it say I have to send something the next day? Why?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I'm not --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Everybody is sending all these next day thank you texts. You thank somebody when you leave. That's enough.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I wanted to do it. I'm not asking you to send me a thank you note. I sent you a thank you note.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But then you had to respond to it.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I know because I just wanted you to know in advance that I wasn't going to send you a next day thank you text if you took me out to dinner the next time. I was going to thank you after the dinner, before I got in my car. Thanks so much. I really appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And you wouldn't --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I kind of would appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: What do you mean?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Because, otherwise, you've just gotten in the car, you've driven off --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: No. WALLACE

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: But I said thank you after the meal.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I understand, but it was a momentary thank you. It means you at least lasted until the next day.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I think that's ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So, tell me something else.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Everyday social interaction that, you know, kind of greases the wheels of humanity that you think is stupid.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I mean, there's 12 seasons worth of it, like the happy new year. I don't understand why anybody would say happy new year to me. I can't even respond to it on a text, happy new year. Why? Why are you sending that to me? I don't -- I don't care. I don't care about a new year. What's the difference? What's the difference? It's happy new year. What does it even mean?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, there's even a better question, which I think is actually one of your episodes. How long after January 1st --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: -- do you have to keep saying happy? In other words --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes, I was nice and said January 7th. But now I'm revising that to January 3rd.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: January 3rd?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: That's it?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: That's it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Do people come up to you and sort of say, almost like a rabbi, how long do I have to say happy?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: They do.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah, I get questions like that.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And you pronounce --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah, and I have -- I have answers for all of them. (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So, January 3rd --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I'm changing it to January 3rd, yeah. Yeah. And here's the thing, because I'm Jewish, I also get the happy new year in September at the Rosh Hashanah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah. And I get it then. So, I'm getting it twice a year.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It's a nightmare.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I don't need it. Don't wish me happy new year. I don't even care if you wish me happy birthday. What do you think about that?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, now we're really treading on sacred ground here. Really?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: No, that's fine. Happy birthday is fine.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: This is interesting.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: But, but --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I've said this in -- I think I did a movie where I talked about this, that the birthday is turned into a job. You're getting 25, 30 texts of happy birthday. They all have to be answered. And it's a job.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, I agree with that. But here's the interesting question.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Do you agree that you have to respond to the happy birthday text?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: You have to say something, right?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You have to acknowledge.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: If I send you a happy birthday and you don't respond, I consider it a snub.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah, it's a snub.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It's a snub. In fact, I question the whole basis of our relationship.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah. So, what I'm saying is I would rather not get the happy birthday text because I have to return it. That's all I'm saying. I'd rather not get it. If you want to say it in person, if you see me, hey, happy birthday. Hey, thanks. But don't send me a text that I have to return. That's a job. No?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: No, I -- I -- I will say -- and God forbid.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: So, you're with me on the birthday?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes, I do agree with you on the birthday. And God forbid it's a big birthday, like, you and I are almost exactly the same age.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I think you're like four months older than I am. Seventy- five? A nightmare.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: A nightmare because you're going to get a lot. And it's not a birthday you really want to celebrate to begin with. And now, suddenly, you've got to respond to everybody. It's a nightmare.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Exactly. So, you know, if there's anything that I can do to change that, I would like to.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, I'll sign up for that, as a matter of fact.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, you've enlisted me.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: So -- so you would rather -- let me get this straight now. You would rather people not say happy -- happy birthday, send you a text, a happy birthday text because you have to return it, right? You agree?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes, except that I have to say I'm a bit of a hypocrite because I do send people happy birthday texts. But guess what? After today? Never again.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Or you could do this. Happy birthday. No need whatsoever to reply to this happy birthday text.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: In fact, please don't.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: In fact, please don't. There you go.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I want to ask you a question.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Because my --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Sure, what do you got?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: -- my father always said, people are fascinated by how much rich people are worth. I remember him famously asking Johnny Carson once, what he's worth.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: That's a terrible, terrible question to ask. Who does your father think he was, by the way?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I think we know.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah, we know.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Okay, so here's the question.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I hope that Johnny Carson said to him, Mike, none of your business. That's none of your business.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: He, in effect, said that. So, here's the question.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: On the internet, I actually looked, the over under is half a billion dollars.(LAUGHTER) No, we're not doing a spit take here. (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: By the way, I'm out of water. Okay? I'm out.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You're out of water?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah. Is there anybody? Can I get more water here?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: No, that's it.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Is that it?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: That was the allotment.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Is that my allotment?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: That's it. No, I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: First of all, how dare you?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You know what? We've had -- I've done a hundred interviews. I've done a hundred interviews.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: How dare you?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Well --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So, that's it.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I didn't think we'd be going this long.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I think you're avoiding the question.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Avoiding the question? I'm going to say --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Over under half a billion dollars.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: -- what should have been said to your father, okay? None of your fucking business. How about that? And that's ridiculous. That's ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: What you just said.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Half a billion?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: That number is so preposterous, okay? Ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: How about a hundred million dollars?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Okay, how about you shut up, okay?(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: How about you shut up? Is that all right?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I've got a say, you know? A hundred interviews? Nobody's ever said that to me before.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Okay, well, just shut up.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: All right, we got that straight. You started in stand-up in the 1970s. DAVID

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And I read a story that one time, you go out in a nightclub.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You look around the room. You scan it. You say, you know what? Never mind. And you walk off.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I didn't say never mind. I said, I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Really? But you didn't say a word.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You didn't go out. You didn't do a couple of jokes.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It didn't fall flat.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: No, I didn't do anything. I just looked them over and I went, I don't think so.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Why?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I just didn't like the vibe.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You didn't like the vibe?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And what did they do? Did they --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I guess they murmured what's going on. I don't know. I just left, yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: In 2016 and 2020, I'm trying to get over the shut up, but it stings. In 2016 and 2020, you --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Trying to get over the what?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: The sting of you shut up. It's a little hurtful.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Hurtful?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: What about your question? What kind of question is that?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You know what Barbara Walters said? There's no such thing as an indiscreet question.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: There are only indiscreet answers.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Oh. Okay.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Okay?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah. I don't think that's true.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It's a good line though.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: It's a good line.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: For an interviewer.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: It's a good line, but it's nonsense.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I wonder how Barbara Walters would react. Barbara, how many times a week do you have sex with your husband? Do you give him head? Do you think she's like that?(LAUGHTER) How do you think she would have reacted to that?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I think she'd say, there's no such thing as (INAUDIBLE). None of your business.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah, okay.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I don't think she would have said, shut up.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Oh, okay. That really stung you, that shut up.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It's not nice.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I think you may need to send me a note tomorrow apologizing.(LAUGHTER) In 2016 and 2020 --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: -- you, on "Saturday Night Live," played a presidential candidate --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: -- that you were more than somewhat resembled. Here you are. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: We're doomed.(LAUGHTER) We need a revolution. Millions of people on the streets. And we got to do something. And we got to do it now. Enough is enough. We need to unite and work together if we're all going to get through this.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Sounds like socialism to me.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Democratic socialism.(END VIDEO CLIP) (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: One, was that fun? And two, did you worry, but being Larry David, of course, you worried, that Bernie Sanders was going to win and you were going to be stuck having to play him for four or eight years?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: That definitely was a concern. Yeah, that was a concern. It was fun. It was fun. It was a lot of fun. I really enjoyed doing that.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And would you have gone on "Saturday Night Live" occasionally to play President Sanders?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I suppose I would have. I mean, I started it. I probably would have, but --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Think about this.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Fortunately --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes, you would have been discomforted, but it would have meant in 2016, the president was Bernie Sanders.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Well worth it. It would have been well worth it, yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Finally, I want to end with the Seinfeld finale in 1998.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Hmm.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Here it is.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: See now to me, that button is in the worst possible spot.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Really? UNKNOWN

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Haven't we had this conversation before?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: You think?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: I think we have.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Yeah, maybe we have.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Seventy-six million people watched that. It was the sixth --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Seventy-six million disappointed people, yeah.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm going to get to that.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It was the sixth most-watched entertainment event on television at that time. And as you point out, some people weren't thrilled. What do you think of that ending? You wrote it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Larry?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Chris? No hard feelings?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I believe that I'll -- I'll get over it.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: You're welcome.(END VIDEOTAPE)
